instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00292: What is 820-00292? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00292</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> iMac 27-inch 2015 no light on diagnostics leds
threads.message:
Hi,

Tried good working power supply - no light on any diagnostics LEDs. Inspected board for corrosion or explosions - nothing. Seems like there are no schematics for this board either. Any known issues with this board? Any idea what it can be?

Thanks!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00292</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> iMac 27-inch 2015 no light on diagnostics leds
threads.message:
Leakage on a Power FET; usually <SIGNAL>12V_S0</SIGNAL>.
Use 3478 and 00291 schemtics...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00292</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> iMac 27-inch 2015 no light on diagnostics leds
threads.message:
Checked voltage on pins 4,5,6, 10,11,12 - 0V
Checked for short - shorted
Replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q8450</TRANSISTOR> (<SIGNAL>12V_S0</SIGNAL>) FET - no short
voltage on pins 4,5,6, 10,11,12 is 0.45V now.
Please advise.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00292</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> iMac 27-inch 2015 no light on diagnostics leds
threads.message:
You should have 12V at pins 1/5; there is <SIGNAL>12V_G3H</SIGNAL>...
If not, post diode mode to ground.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00292</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> iMac 27-inch 2015 no light on diagnostics leds
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00292</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> iMac 27-inch 2015 no light on diagnostics leds
threads.message:
Missing <SIGNAL>12V_G3H</SIGNAL> from power supply?
Check at power connector.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00292</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> iMac 27-inch 2015 no light on diagnostics leds
threads.message: It is 12V on the output cable of power supply. When I plug it in to the board, it becomes 0.41V on J6900.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00292</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> iMac 27-inch 2015 no light on diagnostics leds
threads.message:
"497 in diode mode"
Is that with power supply connected to the board?
No 220V at power supply, of course...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00292</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> iMac 27-inch 2015 no light on diagnostics leds
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00292</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> iMac 27-inch 2015 no light on diagnostics leds
threads.message:
No short, you must get 12V there, when power supply connected.
Check the power cable, between power supply and MLB.

You can test the board alone on the desk, with 12V from lab power supply...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00292</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> iMac 27-inch 2015 no light on diagnostics leds
threads.message:
I injected 12V and the results are almost the same.
I get 1.5V on the connector and 1amp.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00292</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> iMac 27-inch 2015 no light on diagnostics leds
threads.message: Did you inject directly on the <SIGNAL>12V_G3H</SIGNAL> power rail?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00292</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> iMac 27-inch 2015 no light on diagnostics leds
threads.message:
No. First time I injected it at J6900. Now I tried to inject it directly at <SIGNAL>12V_G3H</SIGNAL> and I got green light on the first diagnostics led.
I went poking around for more short and found another one on <SIGNAL>PP12V_S0</SIGNAL> line. Tried to inject 12V there but it only takes 1V since its shorted to ground. Nothing heats up. Whats my next move? Thanks!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00292</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> iMac 27-inch 2015 no light on diagnostics leds
threads.message:
Discard first any shorted high-side MOSFET from a secondary power supply connected to <SIGNAL>12V_S0</SIGNAL>.
Compare short value with ohm value to ground from correspondinf big coils.
If nothing strange, then start injecting with 1V and slowly go up.
Let ampers adjust at max on the lab power supply.
